Tickets Now On Sale For University Prom Dr. Otto Kraushaar
Saturday,March 19,At Regiment Armory Addresses Students
A campaign has begun this
Week for widespread promotion
of the upcoming University Prom,
scheduled for March 19, featuring the Glen Miller Orchestra
under the direction of Ray McKinley, at the Fifth Regiment
Armory.
Prom Chairman Bill White rePorted that tickets will go on sale
in Levering Hall at the student
shop, the dormitories, and at the
Johns Hopkins Medical School
In Hampden House. Tickets
Will cost $2 for undergraduates

and $4 for graduate students,
medical students, nurses, alumni,
McCoy students, and employees.
Faculty admission will be complimentary.
"I want to emphasize to the
undergraduates that they have
already paid half the price of
their tickets in their class dues,
and letting outsiders obtain their
tickets will cost them this advantage," White stated, This is
the second year that undergraduates have voted to tax
themselves an extra $2 apiece in
class dues to assure that the
prom will be held.
White also announced that the

University Prom will be held from
9 p.m. until 1 a.m. and will be
semi-formal with no corsages.
Tickets will n o t be sold at the
door under any circumstances.
The Glenn Miller Orchestra under the direction of Ray McKinley will play music " in the
Glenn Miller Tradition with
authentic Miller Arrangements".
Ray McKinley himself worked
with Glenn Miller on arrangements long before the formation
of the Glenn Miller Orchestra.
Later McKinley went his own
way and soon became one of the
most sought after drummers inthe country.

What may prove to be a precedent-setting decision concerning fraternity-neighbor relations
occurred last week when the
Baltimore Zoning Board ruled a
Hopkins fraternity legally within its rights in buying and
occupying a new house near the
campus.
Following a court struggle-between Phi Sigma Delta fraternity
and the Tuscany-Canterbury Improvement Association over the
fraternity's new residence at
3904 Canterbury Road, the Zoning Board said that "the law
does not prohibit from residential districts fraternities housing
some members."
The decision balked the neighbors' claim that a fraternity is
"a rooming house" and the purchase of the Canterbury residence therefore a violation of
the law.
The resident Association appealed to the board the granting
of a permit to allow the fraternity to occupy the three-story
house on the fact that some
members lived and ate meals in
the house, thus making it a
"rooming house" which is forbidden in residential districts.
The Phi Sigma Delta alumni
association hired attorneys who
argued that a fraternity is a
club the nature of which makes
it desirable that members live
in its quarters and that use of a
residence as a fraternity house
is perfectly proper under the
Zoning Code.
The Zoning Board's decision
will strongly affect future attempts by Hopkins fraternities
to relocate in the neighboring
residential section.

What may prove to be a precedent-setting decision concerning fraternity-neighbor relations
occurred last week when the
Baltimore Zoning Board ruled a
Hopkins fraternity legally within its rights in buying and
occupying a new house near the
campus.
Following a court struggle-between Phi Sigma Delta fraternity
and the Tuscany-Canterbury Improvement Association over the
fraternity's new residence at
3904 Canterbury Road, the Zoning Board said that "the law
does not prohibit from residential districts fraternities housing
some members."
The decision balked the neighbors' claim that a fraternity is
"a rooming house" and the purchase of the Canterbury residence therefore a violation of
the law.
The resident Association appealed to the board the granting
of a permit to allow the fraternity to occupy the three-story
house on the fact that some
members lived and ate meals in
the house, thus making it a
"rooming house" which is forbidden in residential districts.
The Phi Sigma Delta alumni
association hired attorneys who
argued that a fraternity is a
club the nature of which makes
it desirable that members live
in its quarters and that use of a
residence as a fraternity house
is perfectly proper under the
Zoning Code.
The Zoning Board's decision
will strongly affect future attempts by Hopkins fraternities
to relocate in the neighboring
residential section.
